text:
I do not know if it was already discussed, or is schedule for inclusion, but
making an 'if' task would really be great, the if in the target is nice but far
from easy to use.

A simple use case would be (syntax could be better):
<target name="foo">
  <if value="${var}" equals="true">
    <sometask/>
    <else>
      <someothertask/>
    </else>
  </if>
</target>

Currently this is implemented with the less than obvious:
<condition name="fooCondition">
  <equals arg1="${var}" arg2="true"/>
</condition>
<target name="foo" depends="fooTrueCase,fooFalseCase"/>
<target name="fooTrueCase" if="fooCondition">
  <sometask/>
</target>
<target name="fooFalseCase" unless="fooCondition">
  <someothertask/>
</target>

If there is nothing that I could use/backport with the latest stable release, I
could implement it (feedback appreciated for the syntax) and contribute it.

Best regards,
    Guillaume
creator: gtaglang@free.fr
stevel@apache.org
text:
There is an <if> task in ant-contrib.sourceforge.net, which you can declare and
use if you want it.


The reason that ant core doesnt (and probably wont) include an if class comes
down to the difference between declarative and procedural programming. Its a
sensitive topic. Ant already has conditional targets, and <fail> is conditional
too. If these are not enough, get the ant-contrib library.

It takes an INSANE amount of nasty looking target "depends" to do what the
simple ant-contrib <if> task can do, especially since the above example does not
even fully cover it as <condition> isn't valid outside of <target>. 

PLEASE revisit the decision to leave this out of ant core. I want code I can
understand 6 months from now!
